Author: Neel Maitra
Message:
Update the details for AdWyze (#1427)

* fix(adwyze): Update the details

* AdWyze changed their name to Clarisights.
  (adwyze.com redirects to https://clarisights.com/).
  I unfortunately couldn't find any blogs, references, news of this name change
  ; but as an employee I can confirm this.
* The Interview process has changed[1] without violating the criteria[2]:
  1. Culture and Fit Interview: Over a 30-minute call we will outline the opportunity,
     review your work experience and look for signs and evidence of culture fit.
  2. Tech Round 1: It covers areas of Coding & DS and Algo.
  3. Tech Round 2: This round covers the Design part
  4. Offer and Closing: Finally you will meet a member of the talent team to
     close on your compensation details and date of joining. Welcome to Clarisights!

[1]: https://careers.clarisights.com/?ashby_jid=df51643c-4da4-406e-84a9-c95df40de782
[2]: https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/dd94572df0212fdf2720ce2b62a1548b45609d94/CRITERIA.md

* fix(clarisights): Drop the old name AdWyze

Message:
Merge #1276

1276: Add Cortlex company to README.md r=poteto a=Cortleksas

<!--
Thank you for contributing!

Pull requests that do not adhere to the format will be rejected. Please ensure
you complete the following checkboxes.

Please also:

- Add one company at a time.
- Insert in alphabetical order
- Do not sort other listings
-->

## Add/Update/Remove <CompanyName>

- [+] I have read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [+] I agree to the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)
- [+] I have followed the [format](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#format) prescribed in the contributing guidelines
- [+] (OPTIONAL) In your pull request message, add additional context on the interview process if necessary

<!--
Please give additional context about the interview process if necessary.
-->
I share my first-hand experience since I recently joined the Cortlex team. Also, I logged in to a company's GitHub account with the permission of the HR department, which has account ownership.

So, the interview process for Cortlex was spot-on and hassle-free. First, I told a recruiter about myself and described my work experience. After that, we had a call with a technical specialist (who is also my mentor currently; he explains the company's processes and answers my questions). He asked me more about my technical expertise, language, libraries, and databases. There were no riddles and HackerRank problems to solve. Instead, we had a friendly, respectful conversation, and they checked my knowledge of things they use in their projects.

After that - it was all good, and we continued with an offer!

Co-authored-by: Cortleksas <114213498+Cortleksas@users.noreply.github.com>

Please give additional context about the interview process if necessary.
-->
1. Phone screen with recruiter
2. Technical screen in the form of a pair-programming session to debug and test existing code
3. Final round is a multi-round session that typically includes demonstrations for backend, frontend, and design skills (and they are collaborative in nature) but are not odd Leetcode style questions.  There is also a cultural/behavioral fit round, but that does not involve coding/design demonstrations.

1240: Add Poll Everywhere r=poteto a=mdiebolt

Our technical assessment tries to mirror day-to-day contributions as much as we can. It asks the candidate to build a _very_ stripped down version of our core product experience. The follow-up interview is to assess team collaboration and pairs the candidate with a Designer and Engineer to enhance what they built in the challenge round.

Author: bors[bot]
Message:
Merge #1217 #1218

1217: Remove Instacart r=poteto a=samanthawritescode

I applied to Instacart through this list, but won't be going forward with their process. The recruiter, documents that recruiter sent, and further research on Blind, Glassdoor, etc. indicate that they do tech screens through a 3rd party (karat), so you don't even talk to an engineer at the company. Apparently in that screen CS knowledge/topic questions are asked and you're expected to get through 2 leetcode-esque questions in 30 or so minutes. None of this "resembles day-to-day work" to me. 

I don't think that this process fits the spirit of this list at all, but at the very least there's a mismatch in the real process and what's describes here.

Author: Matt Diebolt
Message:
Add Poll Everywhere

Our technical assessment tries to mirror day-to-day contributions as much as we can. It asks the candidate to build a _very_ stripped down version of our core product experience. The follow-up interview is to assess team collaboration and pairs the candidate with a Designer and Engineer to enhance what they built in the challenge round.

Author: bors[bot]
Message:
Merge #1182

1182: Move "pay the candidate for their time" to the top in RECOMMENDATIONS.md r=poteto a=LrWm3

I think paying candidates for the time required to complete take home interviews up to 4 hours in length is a requirement for assigning take home interviews in an ethical manner. Not everyone can afford to work for free for X hours per interview. Given the imbalance of power in an interview setting, asking people to work for 2 to 4 hours for free just does not seem fair.

Additionally, many of the take home interview recommendations are "soft" and somewhat ambiguous. Is a take-home interview 4 hours? are the questions related to the job itself? the interviewer and interviewee may disagree on these points.

however, it is completely umbiguous whether or not candidates are being paid for the time they spend on take-home interviews. companies are either doing it or not. it's harder to handwave away.

This PR moves "pay the candidate for their time" to the top of the take-home interview suggestions list in recommendations.md

<!--
Please give additional context about the interview process if necessary.
-->

For my interview I initially had a conversation with my future manager about who the company is and what they do (which is define and provide materials for primary education curricula) as well as a discussion about the topology of the team in order to get some idea about how the team operates as well as what I could expect systems to look like given that Conway's Law has some merit. The next step was to have a call with a pair of existing team members to discuss my experiences with the tools we'd be using as well as discussing how I have handled pressure in the past, as well as to discuss a hypothetical architecture concept because I would be creating a lot of cloud infrastructure in my role and they wanted to get an idea of how I would approach the sort of problem solving that I would be doing day to day. The architecture concept was realistic, and not esoteric at all.


Co-authored-by: Rodney <rodney.the.programmer@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: TravisR <Travis.Rigg@greatminds.org>

- [x] (OPTIONAL) In your pull request message, add additional context on the interview process if necessary

<!--
Please give additional context about the interview process if necessary.
-->
## Additional context

We have 3 rounds of interviews.
1. First round is the introduction round where get to know the person and their experience. This is done on a video call via google meet. This session lasts for around 30 min.  
If suits fit, we send the take-home task via email which contains a real-world coding exercise very close to what we do on daily basis at work.
2. Once the candidate submits an assignment, we get on a call for a code walkthrough and a further discussion. This is also done via google meet call and lasts for about 1 to 1.5 hours. We focus on fundamentals and **do not ask DS Algo questions.**
3. Last round is culture fit found.


Co-authored-by: Salvador  Tamarit Muñoz <tama@coltrane.local>
Co-authored-by: Mohd Shad Mirza <iamshadmirza@gmail.com>

Message:
Merge #1139

1139: Add Bramble to readme r=poteto a=glennr

Adds Bramble's hiring process.

<!--
Thank you for contributing!

Pull requests that do not adhere to the format will be rejected. Please ensure
you complete the following checkboxes.

Please also:

- Add one company at a time.
- Insert in alphabetical order
- Do not sort other listings
-->

## Add/Update/Remove <CompanyName>

- [x] I have read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [x] I agree to the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)
- [x] I have followed the [format](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#format) prescribed in the contributing guidelines
- [x] (OPTIONAL) In your pull request message, add additional context on the interview process if necessary

<!--
Please give additional context about the interview process if necessary.
-->

Given that we are a globally distributed team and much of our communication is asynchronous, we like the hiring process to resemble the ways that we work each day.

In the spirit of [Automattic's process](automattic.com/work-with-us/how-we-hire-developers), we add you to our recruitment Slack, and we take it from there. Essentially it'll be some general discussion that we'll do asynchronously, and then we schedule a 60 min block of time where you and he will have a more technical Slack conversation.

From there we give you a short take-home coding challenge, and if that goes well a short pairing session to go over your solution.

Co-authored-by: Glenn Roberts <72130+glennr@users.noreply.github.com>

- [X] (OPTIONAL) In your pull request message, add additional context on the interview process if necessary

## Notes
- After the initial 1 hour tech screen, a decision will be made to stop or continue on to the longer set of interviews.
- The process can vary by team. For example, more front-end focused teams will employ a React refactoring problem and a JavaScript/React focused build.
- The sequence of the four interviews is not important. They do not cover the same topic and can be done in any order.
- The manager chat can happen before or after the four interviews and is sometimes used as a decision point.
- The level of the position can alter the amount and type of interviews. The example shown is for a mid-level or senior role. Internships will have less interviews and be simpler. Staff level will have a larger system focus, longer (some are 1.5 hours), and perhaps more (6) interviews.

Co-authored-by: Michael Hoppes <MECU@users.noreply.github.com>

Author: bors[bot]
Message:
Merge #1135

1135: Add EatSleepRIDE r=poteto a=BrentMifsud

Toronto based startup. They have a pretty fair interview process.

First interview is an interview with the CTO. Talks about candidates experience, sometimes will ask to do a code walkthrough or see some of the candidates existing work or projects.

Following this interview there is a take-home assignment that is relevant to the job the candidate will be doing. For example, mobile take home I had to hit their api, and plot some of the locations on the map.

Finally there is a behavioural interview with the remaining engineers and the CEO.

There was a follow call after this to discuss salary.

Please give additional context about the interview process if necessary.
-->
- We use a live-coding site (Coderpad) but only as a shared IDE as we are a remote company. All of the questions are developed internally and are adapted from problems we have solved. We pair with the candidate on solving the coding questions.
- The pre-interview prep allows candidates to process the question and come up with a solution without the pressure of the interview. In the final interview, the candidate walks us through their solution, and after some discussion, we pair with them to implement a feature change on top of their solution.

<!--
Please give additional context about the interview process if necessary.
-->

## Additional context

This is primarily geared towards the iOS interviews (though Android is probably similar). 

The take-home exercise (they refer to it as the "coding assessment") asks you to build out a small app along with a design sheet/spec and to submit the exercise with an estimate of the amount of hours you took to build it (I am a more junior developer and it took me roughly 15 hours, though the UI portion took me much less time). After submission, if your take-home exercise was satisfactory, you are then asked to take part in a video call interview with a few (2-3) engineers - roughly 1 hour long. This video interview involves domain specific knowledge - in my case, it was Swift language fundamentals like optionals, table/collection views, structs vs classes, memory leaks, etc. They also ask some open-ended questions regarding "bigger picture" ideas though this isn't really system design. 


Co-authored-by: Kevin Vu <50222947+notkevinvu@users.noreply.github.com>

Author: Maurício Linhares
Message:
Netflix does leetcode questions, shouldn't be here

Varies depending on the team you interview but I did get a leetcode exercise when interviewing with them, there was no option of a take home test or anything like that.

Please give additional context about the interview process if necessary.
-->

Pluralsight was recently acquired by Vista Equity Partners and now makes prospective hires take a mandatory IQ/cognitive/personality test that asks rapid-fire brainteasers that are not relevant to the position.

The test is called a CCAT. [You can find more information about it here.](https://www.criteriacorp.com/what-expect-the-criteria-cognitive-aptitude-test-ccat)

Co-authored-by: Mario Muniz <mario@mariomuniz.com>

Author: bors[bot]
Message:
Merge #1061

1061: Adds Sixfold r=poteto a=henrinormak

## Add Sixfold

- [x] I have read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [x] I agree to the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)
- [X] I have followed the [format](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#format) prescribed in the contributing guidelines
- [X] (OPTIONAL) In your pull request message, add additional context on the interview process if necessary

Our interview process consists of 3-4 stages, depending on the candidate (and a bit of randomness as to which of the teams they end up being suitable for).

1st step: Interview with HR and one engineering lead, where we give an overview of what we do, and get to know each other a bit better
2nd step: A do-at-home test task, which we don't set a deadline for (but hope you can give an estimate so we won't bother you, if you happen to be busy with something else)
3rd step: A more thorough technical interview, where we discuss your test task, give you feedback and give you an opportunity to meet a few more people from our technical team
4rd step: Depending on the team the candidate finds most appealing, an optional meeting with said team's engineering lead, in most cases acting as a means to just get to know the team a bit better

Co-authored-by: Henri Normak <henri@sixfold.com>

965: Add IT Experts r=poteto a=ChristianVermeulen

## Add IT Experts

- [x] I have read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [x] I agree to the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)
- [x] I have followed the [format](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#format) prescribed in the contributing guidelines
- [x] (OPTIONAL) In your pull request message, add additional context on the interview process if necessary

**Our process:**
1. Invitation to on-site interview
1. On-site interview to assess interest and match on both sides.
1. go/no-go
1. On-site joining the team for full or half day to solve real world problem in driver/navigator style.
1. go/no-go
1. Job offer


Co-authored-by: Christian Vermeulen <info@christianvermeulen.net>

Removing ableton from the list as a close friend of mine recently had an interview for an iOS position and during the call it was required for him to perform some classic whiteboard challenges trying to produce ascii art. They call it a pair programming session. There was no take home challenge and the discussion was not about some real life problem that their facing in Ableton (unless they are generating ascii art on iOS all day long for their products?????). 

If there is any doubt I can provide the whiteboard challenge files that they send during the interview on request.

Thanks

PS. My friend would like to remain anonymous

Please give additional context about the interview process if necessary.
-->

The Heroku interview process is very straightforward; it consists of a manager meet and greet followed by a timeboxed independent project, with debrief discussions about various topics relating to running the project you wrote at scale. All languages/frameworks were acceptable and emphasis was placed on operational knowledge rather than "CS trivia".

962: Remove Mimir from the list r=poteto a=benaduggan

Mimir has been acquired by HackerRank. At HackerRank we use our platform in order to hire which includes the online tests and live coding interviews.

Author: bors[bot]
Message:
Merge #941

941: adds Ghost Inspector to list r=poteto a=simpixelated

Our internal hiring guide explicitly asks interviewers not to quiz candidates on trivial knowledge. We lean on discussing their experience, specific projects, and reviewing their short take-home test (under 2 hours). This was true when I was hired a year and a half ago and remains true today.

<!--
Please give additional context about the interview process if necessary.
-->
The process is very straightforward and the company tries to make it smooth and fast. The first interview is cultural with a recruiter. If there is a match, the next step is a technical test on the context of the job. When the candidate submits the test, there is a technical interview based on the test and to understand if the expectations technically are aligned with what the company offers. Then, if both agree to continue, there is conversation with the CTO to know the person. 


Co-authored-by: gabibrant <gabibrantalves@gmail.com>

- [x] I agree to the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)
- [x] I have followed the [format](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#format) prescribed in the contributing guidelines
- [x] (OPTIONAL) In your pull request message, add additional context on the interview process if necessary

The process for DevOps candidates has consistently been:

1. A Phone Screen - High Level Discussion with Hiring Manager
2. A Take Home - Under 4 hours is desired for time to put together a project to demonstrate CI/CD workflow of a simple application, and knowledge of relevant technologies such as AWS, Kubernetes, Docker, etc.
3. On-site includes a take-home review, which may also consistent of a short (30 minute) live group/team coding exercise to resolve issues the candidate encountered before and/or to complete/improve on current state of the presentation.


896: Add Almbase. r=poteto a=yuvi17

- Adding Almabase here based on my recent interview experience.

- Interview Details:
  - Take home assignment(mine was to design a scheduler service for emails)
  - Discussion on the design and implementation of the take home assignment.
  - Onsite interview consisting of 3 rounds, 1 with high level design, one with low level design and one culture fit.
  - Followed by discussion with the co-founders about company, growth trajectory, career interests, role etc.

Taxdoo applies the following interview structure:
1. On-site interview (remote or in person)
2. little takehome exercise for 4-5 days to see how the applicant structures his/her work
3. followup review/interview (in person) to go through the exercise and give feedback. Includes an informal coffee meeting with other potential coworkers. All travel expenses are covered by Taxdoo.


Co-authored-by: AndreKoTaxdoo <40759144+akowale@users.noreply.github.com>

Our current process is basically:

1. Interview with HR
2. Interview with Engineering
3. Project to do at home very related to what we do
4. Debrief interview to talk about the project
5. Final interview with CTO / Director of Engineering

This process may change depending on candidate/position/etc, but it's mostly like that.

Author: bors[bot]
Message: Merge #869 869: Add a link to No Whiteboards - Allows easy searching of these companies' jobs r=poteto a=dkb868 ## Add/Update/Remove - [x] I have read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) - [x] I agree to the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) - [x] I have followed the [format](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#format) prescribed in the contributing guidelines - [ ] (OPTIONAL) In your pull request message, add additional context on the interview process if necessary I built [No Whiteboards](https://nowhiteboards.io/) which pulls the companies from this repo, crawls their job boards, and indexes their jobs to be easily searchable. I imagine many of the people who come to this repo are looking for a job. This website provides a more streamlined interface for finding these jobs, which they may find useful. So I believe that adding a link to it will provide value to the community. Here is an image of the homepage: And here is an image of the company page which contains the interview description: It is automatically synced to this repo, so it gets updated when people add their company here. It's not perfect, and doesn't get every company's jobs properly yet, but it is being actively worked on. Co-authored-by: Dmitri Brereton Co-authored-by: Lauren Tan

Tara AI started at Gradberry, who was using AI to scrape GitHub and other open source repositories, link them to LinkedIn and thus identify quality CS schools. We proved that there is no correlation between education and the top contributors to open source. We apply this knowledge, and many other insightful learnings about what was previously best practice to every interview we perform.

## Add Canonical

- [x] I have read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [x] I agree to the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)
- [x] I have followed the [format](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#format) prescribed in the contributing guidelines
- [x] (OPTIONAL) In your pull request message, add additional context on the interview process if necessary

<!--
Please give additional context about the interview process if necessary.
-->

Some advice about landing a software engineering job with Canonical:

- Canonical believes very strongly in a fair interview process. Each interviewer is "blind" and hasn't seen notes from anyone else that you interview with.
- At least one interview will be from someone outside of your team.
- The company is worldwide-remote and maintains 24/7 operations. It's possible that an interview may occur late in the evening.
- Almost all of the code that you'll be writing is open source. You should feel comfortable operating in that environment.

Author: bors[bot]
Message:
Merge #821

821: Added entry for NIST to the README r=poteto a=Thomas-Werner-NIST

## Add NIST

- [X] I have read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [X] I agree to the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)
- [X] I have followed the [format](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#format) prescribed in the contributing guidelines
- [X] (OPTIONAL) In your pull request message, add additional context on the interview process if necessary

We have a pretty short hiring process. The first phone screening is done by the Head of Engineering and usually takes 30 minutes. If the candidate seems to fit well, he is invited for a personal interview. In this interview, the candidate is asked to present one of his previous works. If the candidate does not have a project that he can or would like to present, we ask him to complete a take-home task. For junior developers, this consists of the implementation of a small project. For senior developers the task consists of the analysis of a small project with various problems. If everything works out the candidate get's an offer right after this interview.

Co-authored-by: Thomas Werner <thomas.werner@nist.de>

791: Remove TransferWise due to HackerRank and trivia r=poteto a=sebdeckers

<!--
Thank you for contributing!

Pull requests that do not adhere to the format will be rejected. Please ensure
you complete the following checkboxes.

Please also:

- Add one company at a time.
- Insert in alphabetical order
- Do not sort other listings
-->

## Remove TransferWise

- [x] I have read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [x] I have read the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)
- [x] I have read the [format](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#format) prescribed in the contributing guidelines
- [x] (OPTIONAL) In your pull request message, add additional context on the interview process if necessary

<!--
Please give additional context about the interview process if necessary.
-->

TransferWise are now "experimenting" with a whiteboard interview. The actual (timed) exercise requires use of the awful HackerRank interface, and includes several trivia questions where no Google/StackOverflow is allowed. So much *nope*.

As per TransferWise recruiter email:

> **Tech test** - a bit unusual to start with this but we are currently experimenting this scheme and we thank you in advance for your support with this :) This will be a HackerRank online test which I will send to you after this e-mail (pls check your spam section also to make sure it does not land there). This should take you max. 90 min. and if results are good we'll move ahead. Normally we don't have a fix deadline for completing it but will be great if you can do within 3 days or latest within 1 week which should give you enough time I think. Also, pls focus on the coding questions (which will normally come at the end), as those are weighting the most in the final score :) Please also avoid using Google/finding a solution on Stack Overflow


Co-authored-by: Maksymilian Sleziak <maksymilian.sleziak@ageno.pl>
Co-authored-by: Sebastiaan Deckers <sebdeckers83@gmail.com>

Author: Victor
Message:
Removed Shopify from the list (#777)

Removed Shopify from the list. Their new practice is to have a whiteboard puzzle/riddle solving 1 hr session before they decide to move forward with candidates.  

> The Coding Exercise will take place on the screen-sharing, pairing software, CoderPad. Please use the CoderPad to connect with the interviewer at the scheduled time. There's no downloading needed and only requires a strong and stable connection to function. 

As of February, 2019 the kind of questions were: Printing certain geometrical shapes on the screen, sorting a multi-dimensional array, etc.

https://tailorbrands.com
https://tailorbrands.com/jobs
https://tailorbrands.com/about

Interview strictly avoids CS trivia, or live coding on a board.
In rare cases where the candidate does not fit the requirements but pulls the "I learn fast" card we may consider a take-home task (short and easy one) in one of our frameworks, to prove learning abilities, only if the candidate agrees. But this is rare procedure.

The interview is 100% discussion of real-life issues, in system design, scaling, security, and general knowledge.

Author: bors[bot]
Message:
Merge #767 #769 #770

767: Added Falcon.io r=poteto a=zainab-shaheen54

Falcon.io's interview process is more focused on personality and motivation rather than rigid whiteboards. Usually, the process starts with a Skype/Phone interview in which you get to know Falcon and they get to know you for the first time. After that a small project boilerplate, in my case a game, is given with certain completion requirements. After the submission there is a discussion about thought processes and certain choices, and then you will the to meet the team.

Author: bors[bot]
Message:
Merge #765 #766

765: Added SurveySparrow r=poteto a=o-my-code

SurveySparrow follows an interview process which strictly adheres to the no-whiteboard policy. Usually, the process starts with a Skype/Phone interview during which the first level of assessment is done. After that a small project, highly relevant to the job applied for, will be given with a timeframe to complete. Upon the submission of project, if found appropriate, the candidate will be called for a face-to-face interview. The submitted code will be reviewed followed by interviews with a senior developer, HR Manager, CTO and CEO.

Please give additional context about the interview process if necessary.
-->

CJ is language-agnostic in hiring.  The interview process is designed to test for an understanding of abstraction and software design, and not knowledge of any algorithmic or syntax details.  The phone screen is about 90 minutes long, and the final interview includes some discussion, one design question, and a pair programming exercise.

Kata.ai interview process is by selecting the incoming application and set up a take-home assignment appropriate for the applied position. Some position might not require a take-home assignment and only involves discussion during the interview. After the take-home assignment, we will invite the applicant to discuss their assignment and do an interview with them.

## Add Elvie

- [x] I have read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [x] I agree to the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/poteto/hiring-without-whiteboards/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

<!--
Please give additional context about the interview process if necessary.
-->
At Elvie, we highly value our culture and it’s as important to us that you are a good fit in the wider team as well as being a top candidate for the relevant role. That’s why our developer hiring process is more about finding out how you think about solving problems than seeing how you go about solving specific challenges.

We’re pragmatic programmers who have a job to do. We don’t expect you to be able to write a binary parsing algorithm from scratch, but rather to understand that you have the right attitude towards that level of problem solving. We’ll then give the space and support you need to do your best work and learn as you go.

Co-authored-by: Alexandre Couret <alex.couret18@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Lauren Tan <poteto@users.noreply.github.com>
Co-authored-by: Simon Hamp <simon.hamp@me.com>

Author: Patrick McVeety-Mill
Message:
added Headspring to the list (#715)

Here's our interview process for technical positions at Headspring:
- an initial short phone call interview to assess role alignment, motivation, and vision and culture contribution
- a take-home questionnaire to gauge technical-experience and situational approaches
- a take-home coding exercise
- an in-person pairing on the take-home's solution
- an in-person behavioral interview (with no whiteboarding)

Author: Kumar Harsh
Message:
Added Playlyfe (#535)

We don't ask brain-teasers. Since we mostly work in web technologies, we ask our candidates to solve simple problems in javascript (or if feasible, in their choice of language). We keep an eye one how the candidate codes. Most of the times, their capabilities and aptitude becomes very clear from the approach they take while solving the problem, or by their responses when they are stuck, or unable to solve the problem.

Author: Hansen Qian
Message:
Add Affinity (#208)

I'm proposing the addition of [Affinity](https://affinity.co/) (disclaimer: I work here). We've just redesigned our interview process to remove questions that don't mimic real coding problems you see day to day. We ask candidates to implement a children's game (ie. Connect 4, etc), then give a choice between a take-home project or a set of interview questions inspired from tasks we've had to accomplish here at our job. Hopefully they fit the bill of non-whiteboard questions!
